Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Rehabilitating Constants in Sublinear Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The scale of data produced in the world is growing faster than the<br/>ability to process it. One approach for dealing with this data deluge<br/>involves sublinear algorithms, which are designed to estimate some<br/>feature of data without needing to store, or sometimes even see, the<br/>entire data set. Sublinear algorithms include distribution testing<br/>(e.g., estimating if a lottery is fair or not), streaming algorithms<br/>(e.g., finding the most common URLs on the web), and property testing<br/>(e.g., estimating the maximum degree of a network). For these<br/>problems, computer scientists have carefully studied how the<br/>complexity of the solution grows with the problem parameters---for<br/>example, estimating if a lottery is fair requires a number of draws<br/>that scales with the square root of the number of possible numbers<br/>drawn. But results so far have not been able to analyze the solution<br/>complexity for concrete instances (e.g., for a birthday lottery with<br/>366 possible numbers, how many samples are necessary to verify<br/>fairness?). This project aims to change that, by finding solutions<br/>with not only good asymptotic scaling, but good constant factors.<br/><br/>Developing sublinear algorithms with good constant factors will<br/>require new algorithmic techniques. The sublinear-algorithms<br/>literature is based on several widespread techniques like probability<br/>amplification that are simple, general, and optimal up to constant<br/>factors---and significantly suboptimal in their constant factors. By<br/>replacing these techniques with more fine-grained ones, this project<br/>aims to develop new algorithms with better performance in practice.<br/>This project also aims to empirically measure the worst-case<br/>performance of algorithms, by identifying which input distributions<br/>are provably hardest to solve. By testing different algorithms in<br/>practice, the project will discover and compare the actual impact of<br/>different algorithmic choices.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
